title.narrative: Scoping study to identify possible cooperation between the Netherlands and IPSARD in the Mekong Delta

description.narrative: The objectives of this mission were to identify the scope of work and opportunities for collaboration between the Netherlands and IPSARD, demonstrating the added value of Dutch expert advice in adaptive and integrated planning for development. This could lead to providing additional policy advice and contribute to selecting, screening and prioritizing projects that contribute to a sustainable transition in the Mekong Delta, in which men and women farmers adapt their practices.Dutch experts have worked on the Mekong Delta Plan (MDP) (Strategic Partnership, 2013) and participated in projects based on the MDP, notably the World Bank and Government of Viet Nam funded Integrated Climate Resilience and Sustainable Livelihoods (ICRSL) project in the Mekong Delta. The Vietnamese Government has adopted Resolution 120/NQ-CP of 17 November 2017 on “Sustainable and Climate-Resilient Development of the Mekong Delta” (SR Viet Nam, 2017). Resolution 120 provides political support for several MDP proposals and gives additional directions regarding several sectors with particular attention to agriculture, water management, markets and value addition. Resolution 120 provides clear policy guidance for transitions in production and other parts of value chains towards a resilient economy and society. This includes indications for priorities in future agricultural production, shifts in production patterns, and the need to embrace floods as well as droughts and salinity. Challenges in the Mekong Delta (MD) include climate change adaptation; environmental degradation and water pollution; inefficient and unsustainable use of groundwater (causing land subsidence) and sand mining (affecting river flow patterns, and associated with river bank and also coastal erosion); upstream developments in the Mekong River basin such as dam building that affects water and sediment transport; outmigration of rural people, especially young men and women; scaling up of agriculture and aquaculture; and industrialisation, including agro-industries (processing) as well as e.g. expansion of thermal power production which is very polluting. The ATP must address all these challenges, and the proposed SoWs address several of these challenges. This project is conducted in cooperation with: Climate Sense, Water.nl.
